editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE French Conjurer. A COMEDY. As it is Acted At the Duke of York's Theatre. Written by T. P. Gent.
LONDON: Printed for L. Curtis, in Goat-Court on Ludgate hill. 1678.

div.head: THE BOOKSELLER TO THE READER.
div.p:
AS Prefaces are commonly nothing to the purpoſe, even ſo little an Author as a Bookſeller may venture to write one. And to ſhew you that this is as modiſh an Epiſtle as moſt are, I do aſſure you, it has as little in it as any you ever read. In the firſt place I have nothing to ſay about the Play: for as the Author ſtood upon no Reputation in the Acting of it, ſo he has none to defend in the Publication.
Nor has he any thing to ſay about the Critiques: for as he never intends to trouble the Stage agen, he has no occaſion of begging their Favours in Reverſion, and ſecuring of Votes beforehand. And for his Brother Poets, he has nothing to ſay to them neither; no, not ſo much as to rail at them. And laſt of all, the Author has nothing to ſay for himſelf, nor I for him; and ſo I am

lg.l: Since 'tis the Womens Play, I hope you will excuſe
Whate're we bring, becauſe it comes from us.
Conſider what the Stage has done, and Plays,
Of all things, most deſerve your love and praiſe.
And, Gallants, though you are but ſeldom good,
Yet to us women moſt of all you ſhou'd.
No ſooner comes a Beauty here in play,
But ſtrait your Coach and ſix takes her away.
And you who cull the Flock, ſhould be ſo kinde
To comfort the forlorn you leave behinde.
Beſides, no ſooner are your follies known
But Fop on Stage is ſtrait ſo lively ſhewn,
Nay, and his Picture too ſo ugly done,
'Twould fright him into ſenſe. Thus Plays are writ
To breed you Miſtriſſes, and teach you Wit:
And, Gallants, 'twere ill-natured, I protest,
To like the Birds, and yet deſtroy the Nest.
But if in ſpight you'll ſtill grow worſe and worſe,
I will e'ne give you this one hearty Curſe:
May all the mighty Sums you ever ſent
Your Miſtriſſes, be on your Valets ſpent;
And when at Nine months end the Miſs grows ſickly,
May none of all the Brats you own be like ye.

list.head: Actors Names.
list.label: Avaritio, A rich old covetous Spaniard.
Claudio, A young noble Spaniard.
Dorido, In love with Clorinia.
Horatio, His Friend.
Truro, Claudio's Servant.
Monſieur.
Audacio, Horatio's Bravo.
Pedro, A Gold-wire-drawer.
Valerio, Avaratio's Son.
Clorinia, Avaritio's Daughter.
Leonora, Pedro's Wife.
Sabina, Servant to Claudio.
Scintillia, Clorinia's Maid.
Millia, A Maid-ſervant to Claudio.
Servants, Bravoes, Watchmen, Meſſengers.

div.head: The firſt ACT.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: WEll, I am reſolved to win this pretty Creature, whatever it coſt me: I'll ſpend the value of half a Spaniſh Plate-Fleet, but I'll have her.
Dear Sabina, welcome my little Princeſs; if thy Cargo conſiſts of that dear treaſure Hope, unlade, unlade: what news? no ſigne, no light, no glimmering? what hopes? tell me.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Senior Claudio, queſtion not the ſucceſs of your deſigne; for I have made ſuch a progreſs already into it, as will admit of no obſtruction.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Flie to the relation of it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, thus it is: Your dear Leonora, and the fool her Huſband, takes it for granted that I am Servant to my Lady Abbeſs of the Covent of St. Sylveſter; and under that character I have been ſeveral times with them for gold-wyre for the uſe of the Covent, as I pretend. The advantage they hope from the cuſtom of the Covent by my means, gains me a very favourable reception.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And the charge of it, Sabina, I will not grudge to bear; thou mayſt command my whole Eſtate upon this Errand.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well then, if I do not deliver this Fort, with all the Outworks belonging to it into your hands, and before this night be over, may I never bring kinde couple together again, but live as poor and wretched as a Confeſſor in a Gariſon, and as ſhabby as a Bawd in a Pillory.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And if thou doſt, be conſident to be as happy as I can make thee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Marry, Senior, and my own happineſs is ſo material a thing, that ſhould I omit any thing that might gain it, I wiſh all the Curſes of an Aſh. wedneſday may fall upon me.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I fear, Sabina, you will finde it a more difficult piece of ſervice than you yet apprehend: for ſhe is ſo tainted with that moroſe Spaniſh gravitie of ours, that ſhe put the Slight upon the Charms of Treats and Preſents.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Then ſhe's no Engliſh woman, I dare ſwear: for, as I am informed, Treats and Preſents meet with no oppoſition there. I have wiſht my ſelf in England many a time.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sabina?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why, Senior, 'tis the Land of Priviledge for women: the very daughter of a Laundreſs there, after ſhe bears the honourable title of a Miſs, expects, nay commands Attendance and Equipage ſuitable to a Dutcheſs. And for the men, they are ſuch lovers of change of Faces, that 'tis thought if there were a Colony of Lapland, Witches tranſported thither, for the ſweet ſin of Variety, they would ſometime be courted for Beauties. And now I talk of Variety, how do you think, Senior, I might paſs there?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You are pleaſant, Sabina; but all this adds nothing to my affairs: therefore prethy remove the Scene from England into Spain, and tell me, ſhall my dear Leonora

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, Senior, and now you put me in minde of England, I cannot chuſe but pity your caſe, that ſuch a noble young rich Don as you ſhould be put to that toil, that charge, and that trouble, for the obtaining ſuch a paltry creature as a Citizens Wife. An Intrigue with a Citizens Wife in England, is as common as a Frolick at a Carnival here, and has full as little danger in't. There's no locking up their Wives, nor engaging whole Families to puniſh their frailties. If a Gallant be caught in the fact by a Wives Brother, nay, or a Huſband himſelf, he may as eaſie come off for Adultery there, as a man may for Murther here. The Gallant gets but out of the way for ſanctuary, and the Wife gets her Parents to make up the Breach, at worſt, but to pay a new Portion, and all is well. The kinde Cit uſes his Wife that wrongs him, as he does the man that robs him; he had rather have his ſtolen goods quietly agen, than to hang the thief and looſe them.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, but to my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, to your buſineſs; you ſhall have her, you ſhall
have her: I am already ſo forward in my projection, that

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Kinde wench!

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: She's your own, and ſo your Servant Sir. Expect to ſee me come loaded with the beſt news you ever heard in your life: Such a Miſtriſs, and ſuch a Plot

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Hark you, one word more.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Your Servant, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Whirz!—Well, if her wit be as fleet as her heels, the Devil's in't if I miſcarry. This is the nimbleſt little Bawd I ever met with: Moſt of her profeſſion are ſuch heavie bundles of filth, that the very ſight of the nauſeous Caterer is enough to ſpoil a mans appetite to the Veniſon.
Sir, there's a Monſieur came from Madrid would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Go fetch him in.
You are come in a very fortunate minute.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, Senior?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Faith, to give me your approbation of a Monſieur I have ſent me from Madrid.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Dam your Monſieurs, I hate 'em.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Faith I am no admirer of 'em my ſelf; but the Embaſſadours kindneſs I could not refuſe.
Well Gentlemen, how do you like my Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There's a head of hair like the Foreſt of Arden.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And a pair of Breeches like the Crim Tarters Pavilion. The French and Engliſh are ſuch Prodigals, that you ſhall have a French Monſieur, or an Engliſh Lord, beſtow more in cloathing themſelves and Footboys, than would compleatly robe all the Infantry belonging to one of our Spaniſh Armies.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Senior Claudio, if you do not put the change upon his Dreſs, your whole Fortune muſt go to purchaſe him Ribbon, Pantaloons, and Perrywigs.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Fear not that: I intend that one yard of Cloath ſhall make him a whole Sute, and one Mode ſerve him his life.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I would gladly know the reaſon of the mutability of thoſe people: I have ſeen a French Courtier in twelve ſeveral Modes in one day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The reaſon I'll tell you: They make an advantage by it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: An advantage? prethee how?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: They have gain'd ſuch an influence over the Engliſh Fops, that they furniſh them with their French Puppy-dogs for Valet de Chambres.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And I have heard of an Engliſh Captain that threw up his Commiſſion becauſe his Company would not Exerciſe after the French Diſcipline. But your opinion of my Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Gad, mine is, that one born and educated in the very bowels of the various Modes of France, and one that has lived among the Belly-gods of England, can never make a fit Servant for the gravity and ſeverity of our Spaniſh Dreſs and Diet.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Take the Monſieur in, and let the Taylor and Barber be ſent for, and bid 'em be ſure to put him into a right Spaniſh dreſs. Here's a Buſh ſit for a Signe-poſt, and there's a pair of Breeches ſo large, that the motion of 'em is enough to raiſe a Hurricane. Sirrah, let his Breeches be made ſtraight, and ſtufft with Whalebone, to reduce his Limbs into a Spaniſh Poſture. Theſe Monſieurs walk and ſalute as though their Joynts went on hinges.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Let me pray give te little more room in te Breek, for te varre good reaſon.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Your reaſon.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Fait me have to var ſore Breek. Oh te damn'd Oſteler tat ſent a me from Madrid on te damn'd trotting-horſe; and te pockie Spaniſh Gypſey in te ditch, Morbleau.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, I am ſatisfied with your reaſon; your Breeches ſhall be a little larger.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Me confeſs te var great Obligation.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, I finde I ſhall have a hopeful Servant of this Monſieur; but before I have done with him, he ſhall be able to give leſſons of Frugality to both the Courts of England and France.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: We are infinitely bound to my Lady Abbeſs for her good cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: So are we to her Servant Sabina. Well, that's an innocent virtuous Maiden, on my Conſcience.
Look, Huſband, where ſhe comes. Welcome, dear Sabina, how does my Lady Abbeſs?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: She is well, and making heavenly preparation for her ſelf and all her good friends.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that; then I hope we ſhall not be forgot.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Be confident of that.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Then, Wife, we will e'en leave that tedious troubleſome work of heavenly preparation to that good Lady; for ſhe underſtands the knack of it better than we: beſides, ſhe has nothing elſe to do.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Good Huſband, talk not ſo profanely.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Good Wife, by your favour, is it not a little unconſcionable for a man to be put to the Trouble of making proviſion both for this world and the next too?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh fie upon you for a wicked man!

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, Senior Pedro and Leonora, I have a requeſt to you both, from my Lady Abbeſs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What is it, Sabina? but no matter what it is, for I will grant it before I know any further: So will you, Wife, will you not?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But however, Sabina, let us know my Ladies commands firſt: It is not diſcreet to ſubſcribe to a blank.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: It is to bear my Lady company to morrow, being the Midſummer-feaſt: And this, I hope, Leonora, you will not refuſe.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I were to blame, if I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, thou deſerveſt to be curſt by Bell, Book and Candle, if thou doſt. But have a care, Wife, that you do not return as ſome Puritan Ladies have done, who will not admit of carnal converſe with their Huſbands, becauſe wicked and profane, and pretend a command from the Spirit for it; which in my conſcience, if there be ſuch a thing as Divinity in Matrimony (and Faith that's a queſtion, as the world goes now) ſuch a command muſt come from the Devil.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Do you think, Huſband, that my Devotion can ever injure my Love or Obedience?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I hope not, Wife; but you muſt pardon me if I a little fear it: for I have obſerved that thoſe who are ſo paſſionately in love with Religion, never love any thing elſe: All other duties muſt be ſlighted for that. You ſhall have a Wife ſhut her ſelf up for a whole day to prepare for an evenings Veſpers, and then unconſcionably deny her Huſband a whole nights Benevolence to prepare for a mornings Lecture. Out upon her!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, Huſband, if you fear that, I'll ſtay at home.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, go, and take my Prayers along with thee, that thou mayſt return ſo ſevere in Sanctity, that thou mayſt be able to work Miracles, whilſt I get an Abbots Eſtate by ſhewing 'em.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p:
Devotion deſtroy Obedience, Senior Pedro? in that you are
miſtaken: I have as much Zeal as may juſtly title me Religious, yet it never obſtructed my duty to my Lady, or love to my Friend: A hundred Prayers a day I never omit; and I think that may be call'd Zeal.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes marry, and the height on't too. Thou exceedeſt me Ninety eight: two ſhort Prayers a day I can make a hard ſhift to run over, and I think that's enough in Conſcience for a man that ne'er deſignes himſelf a Factor in Piety. I did at a high Feſtival once, but venture at the trouble of Four Avemaries extraordinary, and it threw me into a Fever of ſix months after.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: But Sir, the Gold Wyre. I ſhall be chid for ſtaying.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'll ſtep and fetch it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I ſhall think the time long till I ſee you in the Monaſtery: You will finde a Reception there you little expect.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Indeed, Sabina, every minute will be an age to me, till I am at that pious Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You'll meet ſuch warm devotion there, let me tell you, you'll have a heav'nly entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Here's the Gold Wyre. Was there ever ſuch Obligations thrown upon wretches of our mean condition? Well, Wife, we are the happieſt people in the whole world: Such a Cuſtomer, and ſuch a Lady Abbeſs—I can't but think how ſhe'll tickle thy ſweet imagination with her heav'nly Company.

div.stage: The Scene opens and diſcovers Truro the Taylor and Barber dreſſing the Monſieur in a Spaniſh habit; and all the while they are dreſſing him he ſwears to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Journee Morbleau; oh Diabolo, Diabolo, &c.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Prethy Monſieur be patient; look in this Glaſs, and be ſo wiſe as to grant this dreſs much better than Pantaloons and Perriwigs.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Begar, mater Faſhner, te Devil take you for mine Breek; my foy, me muſt do my beſeneſs in te Breek.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A pox on you; and be glad you have Breeks to do your buſineſs in.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Well, me vill make te varre great complaint to Senior Claudio.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: If you do, the next Breeches I make you, ſhall be ſo ſtraight that they ſhall be laced on.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: But hark you; what ſhall we do for Muſtachioes?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I have an artificial pair will do as well, till his own grows up.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Te little Vig and te grand Muſtach, be var fine tings for te Spaniſh Commodity. Begar, var me in London in tis garb on St. Taffies day, me ſhould be hang on te Signe-poſt for te Jack-a-Lent.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: I wiſh he had been hang'd, before he came hither, that it might have ſtopt his journey.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Now me be te right Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Yes marry are you, and by the virtue of that dreſs may challenge as much freedom as any he in Sevil.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Your Muſtaches ſecure you againſt all affronts.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: My foy, var fine; ten tare for your Mater Circumſiſer—and tare for you te damn'd Faſhner.

div.stage: [Bents one, and kicks tother. Exeunt Barber and Taylor.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Begar me be var glad you be come to Faſhner and Barber.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What have they done?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: My foy, mine Breek be much te ſtraight, and te Muſtach ſo great, tat it much be trouble to ſup the Pottage, Morbleau.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Your Breeches muſt be ſtraight to put your legs and whole body into a right order. Come, let us ſee you walk.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Be not tis var well?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Is not that better than going and ſaluting as though your body were diſ-joynted, and every limb taking leave of one another? Truro, how do you like the Monſieur now?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: So well, that when I die I'll make him my Executor.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Indeed, Truro, me give te var great thanks for te civility.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You are beholding to Truro, Monſieur; and, Truro, you have a great deal of reaſon to eſteem the Monſieur, for he is recommended to me for a man of Parts, and a great Proſicient in the ſtudy of Aſtrology.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Oonds, does he look like a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: None my foy, me be no Conjure, but me have te little acquaintance wit te Star.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: That is an Art I have a kindneſs for. I muſt propoſe a Queſtion to you; if you can give me ſatisfaction in it, you ſhall command what reſpect you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p:
And begar if me give you not te var great ſatisfaction, let
me nere be dreſt A-la-mode again. What be te Queſtion, Senior?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Whether or no I ſhall gain the thing I hope for? That's all I will ſay at preſent: a dark Queſtion I muſt confeſs; but the Reſolution of it will gain you the greater Reputation.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: My foy, Senior, tis Queſtion be deman in te hour of Venus, tarefore it muſt be for te woman. To morrow me will tell you more.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, be ſure you do. Be gone, be gone all.
Methinks, Sabina, I read hopes in thy very looks.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Do you ſo, Senior? That's an argument your eyes are good, that can read at this diſtance without Spectacles.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Be quick, and tell me what you have done, Sabina.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Done! I have made Leonora, and her Huſband both, believe that my Lady Abbeſs expects her company to morrow in the Covent. She has promis'd to be ready when I call her; and I will here promiſe to convey her into what room of your own houſe you pleaſe to have her. When I have done that, do you manage the reſt as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Dear Sabina, do this, and thou ſhalt drein me into Gold: do it, and thou ſhalt finde mē as generous as a Miſer on his death-bed.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Then fear not commanding what woman you pleaſe. Thoſe Embaſſadours from Peru and Mexico negotiate more Love-affairs, than all the Miniſters of Cupid put together. But, Senior, what ſtranger was that I ſee in the Family?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: That's a French man preſented to me by the French Embaſſadour, and a great Aſtrologer.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I muſt needs ſee him, and talk with him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I'll bring you to him.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: What te Devil, muſt me feed on noting but te lang Sleeves, ſtraight Breeks, and grand Muſtach? Begar me do not like te diet var well.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Pox choak you, what would you have? Have you not already eat about three parts of a Pilchard, beſides a diſh of Vegetives? when half a one uſe to ſerve me above three days.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Damn te Pilchar, a barrel would be noting in my ſtomack. Oh te Anglitar, te boon Anglitar, me never break mine Faſs tare, but with half dozen Pigeon, Three four Chicken, good ſtrong Beer, and half dozen bottle de Wine: Was not tat var boon, Truro?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Boon? a Devil on you; if all this went to the making of a Breakfaſt, what the Devil muſt your Dinners and Suppers be? That damn'd Engliſh ſtomack of yours will ne'er make a fit Souldier for the Low Countries. Thou wilt ne'er be like the brave Caſtilian, who can carry as much Proviſion in his Muſtaches as ſerves him a Campagne of ſix months.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Begar, me be ſo hungry, as tat me vill to my Cloſet and make complain to the Star, journee.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Thou mayſt gaze at 'em long enough, before thou fill'ſt that unmerciful wem of thine.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Did you ſee the Monſieur, Truro?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Had you come a little ſooner, you had ſeen a pretty War between him and his ravenous ſtomack. He is ſo hungry, that he's gone to Breakfaſt with Mars, Jupiter, and Venus; where his food will be nothing but heads and tails of Dragons. But if the Coeleſtial Cook dreſs 'em up in foul diſhes, he deſtroys his pocky ſqueazy French ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Where is he gone?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Into his ſtudious Cloſet to ſtuff his Lunatick head, ſince he can get nothing for his belly.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray direct me to him.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Come, follow me then. Well, if there be ſuch a thing as Aſtrology, a State-policie amongſt the Stars, and this French fool be an Aſtrologer, the Coeleſtial government has not over-wiſe headpieces for Privie-Councellours.

div.head: The ſecond ACT.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: OH, Scintillia, what a part have I to act? To gain that little opportunity we have, I am forced to appear willing to live and die in a Nunnery, to humour my Father's covetous reſolution of ſaving a Portion by me. Though I am ſatisfied, I cannot live without my dear Dorido.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p:
Madam, Love was never ſubject to any Law, nor did ever call to its counſel Duty or Reaſon; and if ſo, why ſhould you bring
your Obedience to a doating old Father, in competition with the love and preſervation of your ſelf and Dorido? Let the Sacred Knot be tied, Madam, and then farewel all diſpute. Whether would you ſacrifice your ſelf to a peeviſh old Father, or make your ſelf happy in an accompliſh'd loving Huſband? Come, be ruled by me; ſtear the neereſt courſe to your own bliſs.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I thank thee, Scintillia, for thy advice, and I will uſe all the means I can to follow it. But prethee what's a clock, Girl?

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: About Ten.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: About that hour I expect Dorido. Prethee ſee if my Father be buſie in diſcourſe with that Gentleman that came to traffick with him for Pieces of Eight.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: If Dorido come but at this luckie minute, I ſhall have the opportunity of letting him into the houſe; a bleſſing we rarely meet with. My Father, when he's within, watches me; when he goes out, locks me up for fear of being ſtolen; and when he goes to bed, takes the keys up with him: So that our ſtolen interviews are no neerer than from a Balconie, or through a Window; when iron bars and ſtone walls maliciouſly interpoſe.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: Madam, if Dorido comes now, you are ſecure. Your Father is as ſafe as if he were in Heaven: He is within, counting his Bags at a large round Table ſpread with Gold.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Then I'm ſafe: His ſoul and body are both charm'd to that Circle. Oh that Dorido were but come! Hark, one knocks, that muſt be he.

div.stage: [Scin. opens the door, and enter Dor. who runs and kiſſes her hand.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, the houſe is alarm'd! Your Father is a coming.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Step in here.

div.stage: [Shuts him into another room. Enter Avaritio, with a Bag under his arm, and another in his hand.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Daughter, did you not hear a noiſe in the houſe? I am conſident ſomebody was attempting to rob us.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I heard no noiſe that diſturb'd me, till I heard you.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Why up ſo late, Girl?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Why, Sir, 'tis but Eleven.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Time for young Girls to be in bed.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Indeed, Father, I fell a reading my Lady Sylvanes account of a Religious life; and it ſo pleaſed me, I had quite forgot my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Alas, poor Clor. thou art always thinking of the Monaſtery. I proteſt this Religion does ſo run in her head! Well, have patience, the time draws nigh.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: Yes, to marry Dorido.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, good night, Clo. So, ſo, haſte, haſte to bed, Girls.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: A good night to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I hope he had no miſtruſt of me.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: No, no, this is but th'effect of his Fear, and the product of his Dreams. He dream'd laſt night of his being robb'd to day; and he's ſo great an obſerver of Dreams, that whatever impreſſion he takes in his ſleep, is never to be removed when he wakes.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: Hark, Madam, a freſh alarm. He is returning agen.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: And if he finde you here, we're ruin'd. Oh, Sir, be gone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Muſt I go—I cannot—But if I do, ſpight of the watchful eyes of an obdurate Father, my ſoul ſhall ſtay behinde—

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Farewel, my faithful Dorido. Time I hope hereafter will be more kinde to us.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Were I not conſident of that, I'd ſtay and dare my fate.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, make haſte!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Once more, and I am ſatisfied againſt all affliction.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Why did my fate this pleaſing Scene begin?
Juſt ſhew me bliſs, then take it back agen!

div.stage: Enter Truro and Sabina. The Monſieur is diſcover'd in his ſtudy at his Globe.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Look where he ſits, like the man in the Moon with his bundle of ſticks at his back, peeping into the Heavens as if he were acquainted there; when, in my conſcience, he is as great a ſtranger there as I am.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Prethee call him.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: 'Tis to no purpoſe: His ſoul is got into the body and bowels of the Stars.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: However call him.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Monſieur, Monſieur, are you at leiſure? have you done breakfaſting with the Stars? if you have, this friend of mine would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Donna Sabina! Oh my varre good friend, velcome.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: I'll e'en leave you together.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: What be your buſineſs!

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I have a Queſtion to propoſe.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: What be your Queſtion? tis be de var good hour of Luna.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I am concern'd in an affair for Senior Claudio, and would gladly know what ſucceſs I ſhall have.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Oh, oh, me will tell you preſently.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Dear Monſieur, make what haſte you can; for I am to be at Senior Pedro's the Gold-wire-drawer, about Three a clock: Oh that fair Wife of his! Claudio ſhall have her. Good Monſieur diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Begar, me was ſo intent on te Figure, tat me forgot Sabina; but now me will give you var great ſatisfaction. Tis about te woman, te fair woman.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: It is, dear Monſieur, a Beauty.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: She be te married woman, and her Huſband have te relation to te Gold trade.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: He is a Gold-wire-drawer indeed: A bleſſing on thy prophetick Spirit; this can be nothing but Divine Revelation.—But Monſieur, for a confirmation of your judgement, deſcribe her to me.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: I will. Hole—tis be a woman of te middle ſize, inclining—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Inclining to tallneſs.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: To tallneſs: And as for her hair, it be—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Black.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Var black, her viſage var—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Round.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Round.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Oh heavenly, this is fine!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Let me ſee, her noſe pretty ſize; but ſhe have a mark on her—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: On her chin. You ſay right, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: On her chin, and a mold on her—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Left cheek. Very right agen—prodigious—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Her left cheek. Shall I proceed, and tell her private marks?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: No, no, Monſieur, you have deſcribed her as exactly as if you had been married to her. But to my main buſineſs, ſhall I gain this woman for Senior Claudio?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p:
Me vill tell dat var quick. Here be Sol and Luna in Conjunction in te ſeven houſe, var boon; Jupiter and Venus look on te Aſcend wit te good grace. Begar, if he not get her, me will turn
eiter te Phyſician or Divine, rail againſt te Star, and all toes tat give te credit to deir prediction.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, Monſieur, I know what I know: You muſt deal with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: O fee, fee! no Diabolo—wit te Star, dat be all.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, certainly you muſt have the very ſoul of Prophecie — ſuch a man—Well, you are ſure he ſhall gain her?—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Fait, te more ſure of tat ten te Pope be of his ſalvation.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay then I'll never queſtion it. Well, dear Monſieur, adieu. You ſhall have more of my Company. This Art is ſuch a bewitching thing; and I do ſo love a man of Parts! Well, dear Monſieur, adieu.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Well, well, adue, adue.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Will Senior Claudio be here to day?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I expect him.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: He ſhall be welcome. I proteſt I have not ſeen him ſince his return from Flanders.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you have heard of the worthy deeds he has done in thoſe parts.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Indeed, Son, I have not heard of braver actions done by any man.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Who is this, Sir, that you give ſuch a Character of?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Senior Claudio, Childe.
Senior Claudio, welcome. I proteſt you are ſo welcome to me—

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Senior Avaritio, I have no queſtion of it. The fair Clorinia!
Madam, the world is not ſo juſt in that Character it gave of you, though very honourable. Your Beauty I finde is much above what common fame has proclaimed it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Senior, you are a Courtier, and therefore have the priviledge to flatter without wounding Reputation or Judgement.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, Senior, for all that Beauty you lay to her charge, ſhe's reſolved for a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: A Nunnery, Sir!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Reſolved upon it to a miracle.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Yes, where my friend Dorido acts the part both of Lady Abbeſs and Confeſſor.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: But what do you ſay to this reſolution of hers?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I ſay ſhe does well in it; for ſhe is too Divine for any ſervice but Heaven's.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Now to try my Daughter, I will get Claudio ſeemingly to perſwade her from a Monaſtick life.
sp.stage: [Whiſpers in Claudio's ear, but ſpeaks aloud.
sp.p: Good Claudio, ſee what arguments you can uſe to her to perſwade her from this Covent-voyage: I would willingly have her marry, that ſhe may make me an aged Grandfather.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: It ſhall be none of my fault if you be not one.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: At your requeſt I'll uſe my intereſt.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: But I'll watch your—Now for the trial of my Daughters heavenly inclinations.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Madam, why ſo violently bent on a Nunnery! I grant it may correſpond with the Laws of Heaven, but not of Nature: for ſhe undoubtedly deſigned you for a Mother of a moſt glorious Iſſue, or ſhe would never have rob'd both Heaven and Earth for your compoſition. Can you imagine, Madam, that ſo much Beauty was deſigned to be concealed like a Taper in a Tomb?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Good, I profeſs, Don. Now let's hear what ſhe'll ſay to this.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Senior Claudio, deſiſt—You muſt allow, were I Miſtriſs of a far greater ſhare of Beauty and Parts than thoſe you flatter me with, it were profaneneſs in you to ſay they were ill diſpoſed on a religious life.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh my bleſt Childe! I ſee thou art not to be ſhaken.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Come, Madam, I muſt be plainer with you: I know you love Dorido, and let me beg you to love him well.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Yes, I will love him, and love him truly, love him as I ought.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: What does ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I'll pray for him: That is the beſt and trueſt love, and that's the onely love that I can pay.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Enough, Clor. enough. Come, Senior, I heard all. Oh my beſt Girl! Well, this Religion is a ſweet thing.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Why, did you hear us? If you had not interrupted me, I had made aſtrange diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: As how, Senior?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Onely that this very Dorido that has been ſo long ſuſpected for a Loverof hers, is ſo ſtrangely poſſeſt—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nay, they may e'en go together; never were two ſo well pair'd.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pair'd? how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nay, they hit one anothers humours ſo exactly—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be plainer, I do not underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Why, do I talk Riddles to you? I warrant you, you have not heard then that Dorido deſignes for a Covent?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, not I, I profeſs.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Why 'tis all the talk of the Town. Not heard on't!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Are you in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Why, Senior, as I hope to be ſaved, you are the firſt man that ever told me on't.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, it has been his private deſigne this Seven years, onely he durſt not make it publick in his Fathers life-time, becauſe his violent Father was ſo abſolutely againſt it. But now his Eſtate is in his own hands, the world ſhall not hinder him.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Is't poſſible, Senior? Nay then I'll give him the greater freedom with my Daughter. I profeſs he was the onely man I feared.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: This news is ſo ſtale, that I am half aſhamed to tell it. I have 2000 l. of his in my hands already, for the building of an Hoſpital. He's not a man for this world, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, Senior, I applaud him; he's a prudent wiſe ingenious man, take it from me. This building of Hoſpitals is a fine thing. Truly I deſign'd to build an Hoſpital my ſelf when I was a young man, but my Father, as thou ſayſt, was abſolutely bent againſt it. Building an Hoſpital! You ſhall ſtay and dine with me for this good news.

div.head: The third ACT.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: A Pox take that nitty confounded French man, he has talkt and ſtargazed himſelf into more favour with my Maſter, than any true-born Caſtilian can ever expect to do with all his faithful ſervice. How often has my Maſter condemn'd the Engliſh for being ſuch Apes to the French, and now himſelf becomes guilty of as great a folly!

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I hope not ſo, Truro.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p:
Do you not ſee, that nothing is to be done in our Family,
before application be made to the Monſieur for advice and counſel?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Hold, Truro; he ſhall never command in chief there: I expect a Quarter-maſters place at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Still we muſt be in the damn'd Engliſh faſhion, a Whore or a French Rogue muſt command the whole Family.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Faith, Dona Sabina, I am glad to hear you are like to have ſo great a power in the Family.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Truro, it ſhall be ne'er the worſe for you.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Well, but as I was ſaying before, you ſee that the great Wig muſt be worn again, in deſpight of all oppoſition; the grand Mountach, the grace and beauty of a right Spaniſh face, muſt now, Turk-like, be circumciſed. Nay, the gravity of our Breeches, which for ſo many ages have ſcorned all change, muſt now, within their own Dominions, be outfaced with profane Pantaloons: and all this, becauſe my Maſter is bewitcht with his Aſtrologer.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Senior Claudio, the Monſieur does ſo ſtick in Truro's ſtomach, that except you command a Peace, Wars will enſue.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: The Monſieur merits all the freedom I give him; but did he not, my actions ſhall admit of no controul.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Sir, I have known you the moſt violent againſt the French, of any Don in Spain; but I ſee you are reſolved to make the world believe the Monſieur is a Conjurer: for certainly nothing but Magick could make this alteration in you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No diſputes, but call him in. I ſuppoſe by this time he is in his A-la-mode agen.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: If he be, Sabina, have you a care of him.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why ſo, Truro?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: The air of his great fluttering Wig, and the waft of his Pantaloons, will blow your Coats about your ears.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Marry come out, my ſawcie Companion! I'd have you to know, my Coats are not blown up ſo eaſily.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Stay, Sabina, you ſhall ſee him in his French dreſs. Truro, call him in.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: The Devil, if you pleaſe; for he's the better Companion o'th' two.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I ſee Truro is no lover of the French.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No, he is not. The Engliſh Mechanicks would throw a whole year into Play-days, on condition their great men loved the French and their Kickſhaws no better.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Are the Engliſh Dons ſuch lovers of the French then?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Oh ſo much, that a French Clap is more welcome at Court than a dull Engliſh Ague. Then their Language they do ſo doat on, that they have Maſters out of France to teach French to their Magpies, Parrots, and Starlings. And if their Sawce be not Frenchiſied, their Meat is not fit for Dogs.
sp.stage: Enter Truro, and Monſicur combing his Wig.
sp.p: Now I hope, Monſieur, you are dreſt to your own ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: We, Senior.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: This is a very graceful dreſs, Truro.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Graceful! Pox take him, he raiſes ſuch a duſt with combing his Wig, it's enough to ſtifle one.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: How do you like that Hat, Truro?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Why ſhould his ſhallow Coxcomb have ſo broad a Covering?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Methinks his Breeches are like the Tower of Babel, hung round with Confuſion.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: In my opinion they are like Bells hung in a Steeple, where his legs ſerve for Clappers.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Fie, Senior Claudio, you will deſtroy the Monſieurs good opinion of his dreſs.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Noune, my foy, me like it much te better, for te pleaſure it give Senior Claudio.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Go, Monſieur, you may to your ſtudy again.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: He likes your Spaniſh diet ſo ill, that now will he mount himſelf upon a Cloud and ride into the Heavens to dine with thoſe falſe Fotune-tellers the Planets; a crowd of wandring Gypſies that pick our pockets with a lye, and we are ſuch ſilly fools as to believe 'em.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Then, Truro, you have no great opinion of the Stars.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: No more than of a pound of Candles lighted at the wrong end: for as ſure as I am here, their influence over us at birth is equal. Nay, for my part I declare, 'tis my opinion, that a Candle lighted in the Room when and where the Childe is born, muſt needs have a greater power over it, than a Star in the Heavens ſome hundred thouſand miles from it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, you may ſay what you will; but I have ſo great an opinion of Monſieurs ſtudy, though I think he's no great Conjurer, that I intend to be his Scholar. How like you that?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Shall I be free in my anſwer?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I'll give you the freedom of a Companion.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Then let me beg you not to concern your ſelf with thoſe Starry ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Why, prethee?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Why, would it not be ridiculous for a man of your wiſdom and quality to waſte either time, money, or pains in drawing of a Circle, and then dividing of it into twelve parts, placing a Bull here, a Lion there, a Crab in one corner, and a Goat in another; and then to fall a curſing that old Dog Saturn, that bloody Rogue Mars, that jilting Quean Venus, and that ſlie Cur Mercury, and the reſt of the Gang, for looking aſkew on your Aſcendant: and when all comes to all, and you come to give a grave judgement upon your Houſes with all thoſe monſtrous Cattel in them, faith the concluſion is, Perhaps it may be ſo, and perhaps it may be otherwiſe; and who the devil would give himſelf ſuch a trouble about a Perhaps?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And do you think there's no more truth than this in Aſtrology?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Faith, no more truth in the anſwers of the Stars, than in a pair of Dice thrown upon the Wheel of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I am glad you are come, Monſieur: Now if you can but ſay as much for the Stars as Truro has ſaid againſt 'em,—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Morbleau, what have Truro ſaid agains te Star?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Onely that there's ne'er a word of Truth nor a grain of Senſe in Aſtrology.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Begar, me vill let you ſee tat tare be te much truth in te Star. Had te grand Julius Caeſar take te advice of te Aſtrologer, my foy, he had no bin butcher in te Senate-houſe; nor had Henry te ſecond of France bin kilt riding at te Tilt, if he had been rule by te Aſtrologer: And let me tell Truro, if he no be rule by me, and mend his behaviour, he ſhall die by te Hangman.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What ſay you to this? does not the Monſieur ſpeak to the purpoſe now?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Good Senior give me leave to turn Fortune-teller for once.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Well then, if the Monſieur do not die of a French Clap, be buried in a Houſe of Office, and afterwards be ſung about the ſtreets for a falſe Fortune-teller, let me ne'er feed more of any thing but Radiſhes.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p:
My foy, Senior Claudio, me ſee tat te Star be ſo var anger
wit Truro for his ſlight 'em, tat me fear for his ſake dey vill throw tar vengeance on te whole Family.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Truro, be gone; I have ſome private buſineſs with the Monſieur.
Come, Monſieur, your anſwer to the Queſtion I propoſed.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Awe, Senior.
Tis Skeam vill tell me all.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Shall I gain this woman?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Hole, hole; here be Mars in Conjunction wit te fair Venus, and Sol look var well upon Madam Luna: Begar, if you no get her, me vill draw te Curtain before te Heav'n, tat te Star ſhall no more ſee vat ve do. But te Dragon tail in te ſecond houſe make you pay var dear for her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: That I am confident on already. Go thy ways, Monſieur, if thy Prediction comes to paſs, I am reſolved to write a book in defence of Aſtrology. Yet
No matter what thoſe idle Planets prate;
She is the onely Star that tells my fate.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Clorinia, I am troubled at a dream I dreamt laſt night.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Fie, Sir, the prejudice you have received by thoſe falſe Viſions, ſhould, one would think, make you not regard 'em. What was it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: You are concern'd in't.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I, Sir!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: It was, That thou hadſt changed thy Reſolution for a Religious life.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: That's the greater argument for it: for Dreams are always to be conſtrued quite contrary to what they ſeem.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I proteſt I was mightily troubled at it.

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you have paid a dear rate for the experience of the truth of Dreams. Have you forgot ſince you untiled your houſe for a bag of gold you dreamt was hid in the Roof of it, and when you had done, found nothing but a Sparrows neſt, and ſome few pieces of old Iron?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: And you may remember that another time on the ſame occaſion, you kill'd a hundred head of Cattel, by reaſon you dreamt the Philoſophers ſtone was to be found in their kidneys.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Away, you waggiſh girl.
Senior Dorido, welcome. Well, Claudio has told me all your deſignes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My deſignes?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: About you know what I mean.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What does he ſay?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: My Father has heard of all your deſigne for Religion, your going into a Covent. The two thouſand pounds you have put into Claudio's hand for the building an Hoſpital, is a very pious work.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I underſtand her.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: To him, daughter, to him. Ah, you're well met, I profeſs.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Your pious care—to cheat my old Father,
—to provide for another world, has ſtrangely pleas'd me.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: That's a good Girl. Do you hear, Senior?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Purſue this holy principle, and we ſhall meet together—as often as we pleaſe
—in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: My kinde Father, I ſay,—will ne'er ſuſpect us,
—will make me the happieſt woman in the world—in letting me ſee you often,
—in letting me lead a Religious life, and crown my days amongſt a Quire of Cherubims.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, my childe, my childe! let me embrace thee. This Religion is ſuch a Jewel! Let your fooliſh ſottiſh old Fathers breed up their Children in the vanities of the world, I have a Daughter will make an Angel.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, by your favour let me anſwer her.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: By all means, Sir; your diſcourſe I know will charm her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Madam,—Siſter I ſhould ſay, oh that you could but look into my Soul, and know how much I am tranſported—to ſee you thus kinde,
—to hear you talk ſo piouſly.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Good agen. Well, ſuch a Daughter, and ſuch a Friend, are not in the world agen!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your thoughts, divine Siſter, are ſo much mine, ſuch bliſs, ſuch charms, and ſuch raptures there are—in thy dear Love,
—in true Devotion, that on my knees I vow to live and die—my dear Clorinia's,
—in a Cloyſter.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh riſe, riſe, Senior. Well, you are a good man: Oh, Dorido, this is heavenly muſick to my Daughter. Come, Dorido, ſince you are in ſo good a humour, you ſhall go in with me, and we'll diſcourſe furder of a Religious life.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, I wait on you. But is it not your pleaſure that Clorinia ſhould go with us? A pious minde cannot be too much ſtrengthen'd.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p:
Alas, Sir, ſhe has been reading all this afternoon. I proteſt
ſhe's ſo given to Books, that I am afraid ſhe'll pore her eyes out upon 'em. No, no, ſhe ſhall ſtay and play a game at Cheſs with Senior Horatio. You know Devotion muſt have a little reſpit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pox on him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Come, will you play?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: If I do, I muſt be ſure to looſe. Cheſs is a game requires more care than a man of my temper can have in ſuch fair company.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Come, venture that.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Madam, the opportunity's too precious to be ſo loſt.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Ha! what's this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Onely I dare not play with you, you are too much a Conqueror already.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Nay, then I'll call in better company.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Stay, Madam, hear me but one word, and then call in the Company to witneſs your Cruelty and my Miſery.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: The danger of your Father's return, and the peace your Beauty robb'd me of, will not give me time nor thought enough for a ſtudied addreſs; therefore take it thus:
I love you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Are you in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Are doubts, fears, diſtractions, jealouſies, and all the torments of a bleeding heart, things to be jeſted with?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: And dare you tell me this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Bid a wretch on a Wrack in all the agony of his diſ-joynted limbs, not dare to groan, and be as eaſily obey'd.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: And can you be this villain to your friend? Do you not bluſh? Does not your guilty blood flie in your Traytors face?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Madam, if I bluſh, 'tis not my Treaſon, but my Love that brings that glowing colour in my face. I can't keep down my boyling blood and carry
Such ſire as mine within me. Dear Madam,
Have you no pity for my ſighs? Yes, do,
Reſolve to ſee me die.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: To ſee you damn'd.
Yes, Devil, to thy hell, there thou wilt finde
A converſation fit for thy black Soul.
Had you proclaim'd defiance to your friend,
Renounc'd his friendſhip firſt, and then invaded
His right, your guilt had been more pardonable:
But the baſe Hypocrite's a part ſo abject,
As is below my ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Her ſcorn!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: A Rebel is a glorious Villain, when a Traytor
Is but a deſpicable ſlave. But, Sir,
To put an end to your vain hopes, were your Love
As brave and generous as 'tis baſe and barbarous,
I ſhould abhor the thoughts of him that could
Suſpect me guilty of a change ſo mean:
My conſtancy's not to be blaſted ſo.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, now have I onely rallied with you all this while, and now muſt I expect to finde you as furious as an Amazon, for this trick I have put upon you; never to ſee your face agen is the leaſt Compoſition I can make.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: How, Senior!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: 'Twas an odde exploit, an Artifice I uſed to try your Conſtancy, and my friends Intereſt. And now this rage and ſcorn from you, confirms his happineſs and my hopes.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: A Tryal of my Conſtancy call you it? Did not your zeal for your friend atone for you, I know not how I ſhould bear ſo bold a piece of curioſity.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Never was an Heretick in an Inquiſition ſo baited as I have been.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Daughter Clo. daughter!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Friend,

I know 'tis towards bed-time with this old fool, and he always takes the Keys up with him; and I have not ſaid half my minde to my dear Clorinia: Take an occaſion of telling her, I deſire a little diſcourſe with her at the Parlour-window at Eleven; by that time he'll be aſleep. She knows the old ſigne.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, Daughter, this Dorido is a fine man I profeſs; I once deſign'd him for thy Huſband—

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: How this old Gentleman can diſſemble!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p:
But now you have both made a better choice. Senior Dorido, [Horatio and Clorinia whiſper.
there are ſtrange bleſſings in ſtore for you: So pious a minde in a young man, and a Gentleman too, I profeſs is admirable.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Enough, I'll ſteal down to him.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Daughter.
Senior, good night. Well, I proteſt he is a miracle.

div.stage: Exeunt Avar. and Clor. one way, and Dor. another.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Her Conſtancy is the Rock on which I ſplit; I muſt make her hate Dorido; remove the Giant, and the Maid's my own. I am none of thoſe whining Lovers that can fall ſick and die at the feet of a Denial.
I will go on, and ſcorn a baſe retreat;
Deſpair the Coward onely does defeat.

div.head: The fourth ACT.
div.stage: Enter Horatio, and Audacio holding a Flambeau.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: CAn you be nimble and dextrous, Maſter Engineer?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: As a Mercury, Senior.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Then thus: Watch at the turning of this ſtreet, and when you ſee Senior Dorido come by, put out your Light, and that ſhall give me notice for my Deſigne. When he hears the noiſe I ſhall raiſe, I know he will make up hither; then do you alarm the Watch, and play the part I order'd you.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: To a tittle.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: To your Poſt quickly, the minute draws nigh; 'tis neer Eleven.
Now muſt I act the ſubtleſt piece of Treaſon
That Love, animated
By Jealouſie and Revenge, could e'er inſpire.
I love Clorinia, and conſequently hate
Her darling Favourite Dorido;
And what we hate, we're prompted to deſtroy.

Tis true, I am falſe to my friend; but what's friendſhip in one ſcale, when Love is in the other? Love is a paſſion that's taught and rooted in our Souls by nature, when Friendſhip is but a humour put off or on at pleaſure. Love comes by force, and Friendſhip but by choice, and is but generally the Creature of Fear or Intereſt.
Ha! he has put out his Light, and Dorido's coming. Now for my ſigne.

div.stage: [Whiſtles; at which a Caſement opens, and Clorinia ſpeaks from within.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, dear Dorido, my unkinde Father is not yet in bed, and I am in ſuch danger here, that I cannot tell you half the kinde things I have to ſay. Let that Letter ſpeak for me.

div.stage: Gives him a Letter through the Caſement, which he takes, and as he takes it ſtabs her Arm with his Dagger.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: So, take that Letter and Dagger, and convey 'em into Dorido's pocket.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Death and Confuſion! My Clorinia's voice! What infernal ſound is this?

div.stage: Enter Avaritio in his Night-gown, and Clorinia with her arm wrapt in a bloody Handkercher, Scintillia with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Ha, murder! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, as I was going up to bed, I ſaw the Parlour-window open, and as I went to ſhut it, ſome wicked villain caught me by the hand and ſtab'd his Dagger into my arm.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Lightning blaſt him for't.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Geraldo, Diego, Sanco, Franciſco, riſe you rogues. Dorido!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There's no ſtaying till your Servants riſe: the villain will be gone beyond their reach. Do you run and fetch a Surgeon, and let my Sword purſue the impious Devil.

div.stage: [Exit Avaritio one way, and as Dor. offers to go another way, he is met by Horatio's friend with the Alguazile and Guards.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: That's he, ſeize him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Bold ſlaves, what's this for?

div.stage: [They fight with Dorido, and take him.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Are you the Lady that cried out murder?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Yes, what then?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, this is the barbarous villain that ſtab'd you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I the villain!

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Hey day! now has he the impudence to deny it. Did not I ſee you ſteal up to that houſe, then whiſtle, and a Lady put her hand out of that window and give you a Letter; which you received, and returned the Compliment with your Dagger?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Blaſphemous dog! Is the Traytor diſtracted?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I am all amazement!

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Do you intend to face me out of my ſenſes? Madam, I thought he had been going to rob the houſe, and watch'd him, and ſaw him do't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hell and Damnation! Traytor, Lyer, Hell-hound, what did you ſee me do?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: What I'll juſtifie to be true. Nay, I am ſure the Dagger muſt be about him, or not far off: for he did not ſtir one ſtep, Gentlemen, before I call'd you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Dagger about me! ſearch me, Devil.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Search him, Gentlemen.

div.stage: They pull a Dagger and a Letter out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.p: A bloody Dagger, and a Letter for one Senior Dorido.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Did I not tell you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha! what inchanting Fiend has convey'd that Dagger into my pocket? Madam, if there be truth in Heav'n, or faith in man, I could no more be guilty of this Outrage, than I could burn a Church. Some malicious Devil, envying our Loves, has us'd this artifice to undo me.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: If there be truth in Heav'n, or faith in man, this bluſtring Gentleman is as truly guilty of this Outrage, as you are the infortunate Lady that ſuffer'd it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Infamous Varlet! what art thou, that ſuch an Imputation ſhould be believed from thy mouth?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Gentlemen, convey us both before the next Judge; I am ready to atteſt by oath what I have ſeen and known.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray lend me your Priſoner for one minutes diſcourſe. Ungrateful man!
Is this your beſt return for all my kindneſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And can you perſecute me too? My angry ſtars
And this falſe impudent ſlave, has made me mad.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: No, your guilt, not he, has made you ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Madam, by all that's good, I neither receiv'd that Letter nor ever ſaw that Dagger, whatever Magick convey'd it into my pocket. I heard you cry out Murder, ran in to your aſſiſtance, ſaw you bleeding, and my Soul bled for you.
I heard your ſhreeking voice with ſo much horrour,
That I'd have given my Life, and half my right
To Heav'n, to have reach't the villains heart for't.
And can this be the man that ſtab'd Clorinia?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: No, Sir, theſe Evidences are too plain.
Convey'd by Magick thither! If there be ſuch a thing as
Magick, 'tis in impious mens falſe Oaths and broken Vows,
That can bewitch believing Virgins hearts,
And uſe 'em as thou doſt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, as you'd keep me on this ſide Hell,
And hold my hand from tearing out my heart,
Oh, do not lay this horrid Crime againſt me:
A Crime ſo diſtant from my purer thoughts,
As my heart trembles but to hear.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: They that can prove ſuch Traytors as thou art,
Want not pretences to ſeem innocent.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And can you ſtill ſuſpect ſuch faith as mine?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Did I for this run to the window
With as much haſte and zeal to meet you there,
As a departing Saint mounts up to Heav'n!
And when, like a poor fond miſtaken fool,
My eager hand ſo kindly gave that Letter,
And in it all the tendreſt thoughts that Love
Could e'er inſpire; this cruel man,
When he receiv'd my very Soul,
Could barbarouſly ſtab the hand that gave it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, cruel ſavage woman!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Take him hence.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, my beſt Angel, hear me.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, my Devil!
Make haſte, take him away: and, perjur'd man,
Tell the new Miſtriſs, for whoſe ſake you did
This helliſh deed, to make your title good,
You ſeal'd your falſehood in Clorinia's blood.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: What lazie Rogues are theſe Phyſicians! he was in bed, and I was forced to ſtay till the reverend fool riſe.
Ha! Girl, where's Clo?

sp.speaker: Scin.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, ſhe's gone in almoſt diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns, diſtracted! The loſs of blood will put her in a Feavour. Dear Sir, make haſte.

div.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Senior Pedro and Leonora.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I wonder Sabina comes not; it is about the time of her appointment. What a Pettycoat have you got on there, Wife?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Huſband: My Lady Abbeſs I know hates a gawdy dreſs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, a modeſt garb certainly becomes Devotion beſt.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I am afraid I have ſtaid to the prejudice of your patience.

sp.speaker: Leon,
sp.p: No, I have a greater ſtock than ſo. But I pray how does my Lady?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Very well. Dear Leonora, ſhe will expect us. Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: She got no ſleep to night for thinking of this Holy voyage.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: And Claudio will keep her waking a little longer.
Good woman, her thoughts are on Heav'n. Well, I hope the Monaſtery is not out of the road to it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'll lead you to the door. Well Wife, when you are in your Altitudes, have ſome little thought on the good man at home.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Since this Monſieur got into his French dreſs, he ſtruts it at a wondrous rate: But I hope once more to uncaſe him, and bring that rotten Carcaſe of his into Spaniſh fetters again.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Truro, be wiſe, and te Star will be your good friend.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Oh, plague light upon the nonſenſical babling of your Stars, and all your French acquaintance with them.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: My foy, Truro, you have much te pride, and tat be no boon. Te French man get var great regard from te Engliſh Lord, by tare great ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Millia, be ſure when you hear any knock at the gate, look out of the window; if they be women that enquire for Dona Betrix, be you quick in opening the door and ſhewing 'em a room.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: I ſhall, Senior.

sp.speaker: Claud,
sp.p: And let not one of you appear beſides. Go, be gone every one about his buſineſs.
And now will I to my Chamber and expect my call.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Oh, dear Madam, I had almoſt forgot Dona Betrix, though I promis'd to call her: that's the houſe; come, Madam, I muſt beg your pardon for one minute.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I am ſolely at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Who's there? and who would you ſpeak with?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Is Dona Betrix within?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Yes. I'll come and conduct you to her.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You ſhall go with me, we ſha'nt ſtay.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Uſe your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Will you be pleas'd to walk in, and I'll acquaint her.

div.stage: Exeunt Millia, Sabina and Leonora; and enter again in a Dining-room.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.p: Will you reſt your ſelves here till I return?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Millia, I'll go along with you. Dear Leonora, aſſure your ſelf I'll make a quick diſpatch.

div.stage: Exeunt Millia and Sabina, and lock the door.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O Heav'ns, my Virtue is betray'd!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: My deareſt Leonora! welcome. Now, my beſt life, thou'rt mine. Dear Madam, ſurrender, and ſave the trouble of a ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You may thank wretched Sabina for it. Is this the Monaſtary, thou wicked Hag—and are you my Lady Abbeſs—How durſt you act ſo villanous a part under ſo holy a pretence?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Dear Madam, look but into the Affairs of the world, and you'll diſcover the Maſk of Religion frequently put upon worſe deſignes than this.
Come, my pretty Saint, this inclination of man to your Sex is ſo univerſal, as renders it not ſuch an offence to Heav'n, as men of Holy Orders are pleas'd to tell us 'tis: No, no, dear Leonora.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: How can you talk ſo! Were I convinc'd it were no Crime, yet the blemiſh it would throw upon my Reputation, will never ſuffer me to yield.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Your Reputation, on my life, ſhall not be wounded.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What! and yield to your baſe deſires?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: The Light ſhall be no witneſs to what we do; and a thing ſo conceal'd can never call your Honour into queſtion. 'Tis not the doing of a thing, but the knowledge of it after 'tis done, that gives the fatal blow to Reputation.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: However, vile man, 'twill wrong my Huſband.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: It can be none to him, ſo long as his ignorance has no other opinion of you than what's juſt and honourable. But I delay my joys—Come, dear Madam—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you make me ſtark mad: What do you mean, you wicked laſcivious man you?—

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nothing, dear Leonora, but all the Kindneſs, all the Love, and all the Raptures in the world.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Touch me if you dare! I'll tear your eyes out: If you come but neer me, I'll—nay I'll—

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why, what will you have me do? Well, this opportunity's a meer Devil!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Conſent to make me the happieſt man that lives.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I proteſt 'tis not in my nature to uſe ſo fine a Gentleman unkindly. Alas, I would ſubmit to any thing, and make you happy, if I durſt: But oh, the ſin, the ſin! I won't; let me go, you are a villanous man, would betray my Honour, damn my Soul, and—I hate you. I'll cry out; help, murder!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, dear Leonora, I'll grant you your deſire. I will deny my ſelf the greateſt happineſs Beauty can give, and man poſſeſs, rather than force that bliſs you cannot yield. But, divineſt Madam, if you could be kinde, what charming Magick would there be in thoſe dear Arms, what Nectar in thoſe Lips, and what Elyſium on that ſoft Boſome!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, go on, you ſpeak ſo prettily! Though I muſt never yield to any wicked thing, yet we may talk as kindly as we pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And is that all?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No, Sir, were I a ſingle woman, or if you were my Huſband, or ſo, I could deny you nothing—But—

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, I'll ſend for a Prieſt, and marry you preſently.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Two Huſbands! Alas, Sir, I have too much of one already.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Madam, your ſweetneſs has ſo tranſported me, that if you cannot yield, I muſt force you—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But are you ſure you'll force me? for I vow I won't go willingly.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I'm paſt all patience.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Stay, Sir, if I muſt go, let us reſolve to be as little wicked
as we can: Let's ſtay and ſay our Prayers before we go.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Let's love firſt, and pray afterwards.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But you ſhall promiſe me firſt you will not uſe me too roughly, for my poor Huſband's ſake.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I'm a tender-hearted man;
Indeed I'll be as gentle as I can.

div.head: The fifth ACT.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: WAs ever ſo much inhumanity!
How are my Thoughts diſtracted! Well, if this
Perfidious Dorido be what I ſuſpect him,
His Love defaced, and ſuch a Monſter made,
No Angel ever fell ſo ſoon, or turn'd
So black as he. The change appears ſo dreadful,
That I dare ſcarce believe my Eyes and Senſes.
My Father and Horatio! This interview
May give ſome new diſcovery. I'll o're-hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: This Dorido is the wickedſt Rogue that ever breath'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, he's all wickedneſs. His very pretences for Religion were all baits to trapan you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: The truth on't is, he lov'd your Daughter, and deſign'd to ſteal her.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Steal her!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And all his fair diſguiſes of Devotion were but to gain acceſs to accompliſh it.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pretious Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I am all aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And becauſe ſhe refus'd to break open your houſe laſt night, and run away with him, he ſtab'd her.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Dainty Rogue!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Death, what a Traytor's here!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Sir, I confeſs he was my friend, and under that name I long
concealed his crimes; but now they are grown too odious for my friendſhip to wink at: my zeal for Juſtice, and my ſence of your Injuries, h • ve waked my ſleeping Reaſon. I cannot ſee you cheated and abuſed.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Then belike all this Monaſtery-buſineſs is laid by.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: The devil of any ſuch place did he e'er intend to trouble.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: And I warrant he'll build no Hoſpital neither.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: An Hoſpital! a Bawdy-houſe. He build an Hoſpital! No, Sir, his hot Spaniſh blood will finde other uſes for his money.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: What's become of the two thouſand pounds in Senior Claudio's hands?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Call'd in agen, I can aſſure you: 'twas onely laid there for a bait for you. Sir, to be plainer with you, I do not like your Daughters proceedings.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: How, my Daughter!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I ſay, ſhe's to blame, to have Love in her heart, and Religion in her tongue.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: This is beyond all ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: How! is not my Clo for a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: She's no more for a Nunnery than you are for an Alms-houſe.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: No Nunnery!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: They onely maſqueraded with you all this while. Their midnight-aſſignations at your Parlour-window, have ſecur'd her from ever troubling a Monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Monſter, Barbarian!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: O Rogues, Cheats, Gypſies! Franciſco, Diego, Sancho, Geraldo.

Sancho, ſend for a Maſon: I'll have the Parlour-window next the ſtreet taken down, and the wall made up; and, you Raſcal, ſee that no body comes into my houſe without my orders. I ſhall have this Rogue come in diſguiſe into my houſe, and ſome Ganonical Thief ſteal like a Pimp in after him, and marry them. But now I think on't, I am a Magiſtrate, and will give every body their Oaths that comes within my doors. And, Sirrah, do you ſee that the Balcone be nail'd up: The Gypſie may drop down Love into the ſtreet. Cheat her old Father! And, you Raſcal, take notice theſe two Rooms are all the walk I allow her. Aſſignations! I'll ſpoil their ſport.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Pray, Senior, do me the favour, when you tell whence you had this intelligence, not to name your Author. I am unwilling to gain a fair Ladies diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I profeſs, Sir, I will not ſpeak a word of you. Cheat her old Father!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sir, I am afraid I have diſturb'd you: I'll take my leave of you till ſome other time.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I profeſs you are the beſt friend I have in the world.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Not one word of me.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable.
Run away with a young Raſcal! I'll watch your waters, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Well, I am the moſt unfortunate of women!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What's the matter, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, Brother, had you been here, you had diſcover'd the vileſt piece of Treachery—That Barbarian Horatio, Dorido's falſe friend, has diſcloſed all our deſignes, and ſo incens'd my peeviſh old Father, that theſe two Rooms are my Priſon, and my Servants my Jaylours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And can Horatio be ſo great a Villain!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: This is the leaſt of my Misfortunes. I have abuſed the beſt of men. Now am I certain 'twas this villain ſtab'd me; and I, unhappily deceived by that mercenary ſlave the accomplice in his deſigne, have laid the Crime upon the guiltleſs Dorido; and to compleat my miſeries, muſt never ſee him more.

div.stage: Enter Claudio and a Servant of Avaritio's, with Monſieur and Truro.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Prethee thank thy Maſter for my admiſſion; but tell him
I have no deſigne upon his Daughter, that he need be ſo cautious.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be not angry with me, I onely execute my Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Begar, deſe Spaniſh Lady be kep up as cloſe as de Jack in box, Morbleau.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Senior Claudio, you are come to ſee the unhappieſt Maid that Fortune ever perſecuted.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Aye, Madam, with much ado I am come to ſee you; but your Father keeps a pack of the moſt ill-natur'd Raſcals about him.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, they are my Jaylours. That Monſter Horatio has diſcover'd all our plots, and I muſt never ſee Dorido agen.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I fear you will not.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
His grief and his diſtractions for your unkind ſuſpition,
have ſo dejected him, that you'll either never ſee him more; or ſo alter'd, that you'll ſcarce know he was the man that loved you.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you ſtab me to the very heart.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: That attempt upon you was ſo far from being his act, that 'tis impoſſible but it muſt be done by ſome malicious Rival or Devil.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: That Devil is Horatio: And I like an inchanted fool could ſuſpect the innocent Dorido; and as a juſt Reward for my ſuſpition, I am for ever doom'd to live immur'd within theſe walls. I've ſo much injur'd the unhappy Dorido,
That I can no ways recompence his griefs,
But by ſome bold adventure for his ſake.
What is't I would not do for that brave man?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Siſter, let's ſet ſome new deſignes afoot.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Deſignes! I'll fire the houſe, and run away with him.
'Tis no mean act can expiate my Crime.
To talk of Monaſteries, and delude
A credulous Father, is too mean a ſervice.
I cannot teſtifie that love I bear him,
But by ſome noble Paſſage to his Arms.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: This kindneſs, Madam, will revive him. But, Madam, you ſhall ſteer a ſafer way: I have a new plot.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: To rob your Father. You know he's covetous, and could we neatly and handſomly be maſters of two or three of his Bags, the fright 'twould put him into to looſe his Money, and the way that I'd propoſe to finde the Thief, ſhall bring you into Dorido's very Arms; nay, you ſhall marry him before your Father's face.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: 'Tis a brave Project, if it do but take.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Truſt to my Conduct.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But now I think on't, Sir, his Money is all out at uſe. Yet now I think on't, I have found a way as well. My Father, about ſix months ſince, lent a Spaniſh Lord Six hundred Ducatoons upon a Necklace of Pearl. I'll ſteal that: and as good luck would have it, he is juſt now gone into his Cloſet. I'll after him; and whilſt I hold him in a Tale, I'll ſteal it: 'tis in a little box, and will be eaſily ſlipt into my pocket. I'll be with you preſently.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Good luck attend you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Truro and Monſieur, my two truſty Servants, ſhall be in the Plot. This Monſieur, you know, has ſet up for an Aſtrologer:
I'll perſwade your Father he is a Conjurer, and can raiſe the Devil to get his Pearl agen: and ſo we'll wheedle the old Gentleman, with your Brother and you, to my houſe, where Dorido diſguiſed ſhall attend us; and whilſt the Monſieur is charming your Father to get his Pearl agen, a Prieſt ſhall be there and conjure you two together.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I like it rarely!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Truro, when Valerio returns, and brings the Pearl, do you ſlip out and diſguiſe your ſelf, and come in this Lord's name to demand the Pearl.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: I'll do the buſineſs. Within three or four doors lives a Barber of my acquaintance, he ſhall transform me. But, Sir, the Lord's name.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, what ſhall we do for his name?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: As I remember I have heard my Father ſpeak of him. His name is Don Antonio Don Rinaldo du Peralta.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have it.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: As I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I began a very ſerious diſcourſe with him, and I had ſcarce ſpoke ten words, but he fell ſo horribly a railing againſt you as amazed me. And whilſt he was buſie in the heat of all his fury, I perform'd the Operation. But ſee, he's here!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Huſſey, are you there? You are an excellent jilting Baggage: Nothing would ſerve your turn, but cheating your old Father, would it?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Cheat my old Father! Heav'n defend me!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, no, not you. You have done nothing: Onely lov'd Dorido, made Midnight-Aſſignations with Dorido, and contriv'd to run away with Dorido; that's all.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Who I, Sir!

sp.speaker: Avar.
