sp.p: Oh, do you ſtart! You ſee I have found you out. Theſe young ſluts think they have all the Wit, and their ſilly old Fathers want Senſe: but, Huſſey, you ſhall finde you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Indeed I never intended any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Huſſey, you lye. I know your haunts, Miſtriſs. My Parlour-window has been ſweetly viſited between you; but I'll ſtop your peep-hole. If I had not diſcover'd you, I ſhould have been made a Grand-father through the Caſement. Is this your pretence for Religion! You'll make a precious piece of Nuns-fleſh.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Come, Senior, you muſt forgive her; Love is a Paſſion that can't be reſiſted. If ſhe have tranſgreſt a little before-hand, ſhe'll make never the worſe Nun for't afterward.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, I'll ne'er forgive her. Forgive the Baggage!

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Senior Avaritio.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: With me, Senior?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: From my worthy Patron Don Antonio Don Rinaldo du Peralta.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I have the honour to keep a Neck-lace of Pearl belonging to his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Senior, the Six hundred Ducatoons, with the Intereſt and Principal, are in Don Oreate the Goldſmiths hands, whither I am commanded to deſire your company; where, upon returning the Pledge, the Money ſhall be paid.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I'll fetch it, and wait upon you to his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Now, Truro, when he comes back and miſſes it, bear up briſkly to him.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Valerio, Valerio.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: It works. To him quickly.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Valerio!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Now, Monſieur, can you bluſter out a few hard words, and Hocus pocus him dextrouſly?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Let me alone for de ſheat: begar, me vill repreſen de Conjure tolde life.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: When we have him at our houſe, we'll humour it rarely. I have Trap-doors, and God knows what: and we'll raiſe Thunder and Lightning, and play the Devil and all.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Undone, undone, undone!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh the Pearl, the Pearl!

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh 'tis ſtolen, loſt, gone! I'm betray'd, I'm robb'd, I'm ruin'd! Unconſcionable Rogues, Six hundred Ducatoons at one clap!

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p:
Six hundred, Sir! Two thouſand, Senior, two thouſand:
It coſt my Lord no leſs; and, though I ſay't, 'twas a penieworth.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Worſe and worſe! I am blown up! my heart, my life, my blood's all gone!

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Truly, Senior, I pitie your loſs, conſidering you muſt pay my Lord the price on't to buy another.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pay the price on't!

sp.speaker: Truro.
sp.p: Why, Sir, do you think my Lord will not have ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Satisfaction! Let him ſtab me, drown me, hang me, ſend me to th'Gallies; do any thing with me. Two thouſand Ducatoons!

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Well, Senior, be not dejected; I have ſome comfort for you.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: My good Lord—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, ſweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: My good Lord—for my ſake—do you mark it—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: You are a kinde man.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: For my ſake (take notice) ſhall bate you (pray obſerve me) ſhall bate you (do you ſee) Fiftie Ducatoons. You ſhall pay him but Nineteen hundred and fiftie.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Plagues and Furies! Had I loſt both my Eyes, an Arm, and a Leg, 't had been nothing; but this affliction is unſufferable.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: You may ſee how Heav'n is angrie with you, and lays this calamitie upon you for afflicting your poor innocent obedient Daughter; and abuſing ſo honeſt and ſo worthie a Gentleman as Senior Dorido.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: He's a Rogue, he's a Villain; 'tis he has ſtolen my Pearl, he's a Thief: bear witneſs, Gentlemen, I ſay he's a Thief, I ſay he ſtole the Pearl; nay, I'll vow he ſtole 'em. I'll go inſtantly to a Judge, have him apprehended and hang'd for ſtealing 'em, and then beg his Eſtate to pay for 'em.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh fie, Sir, how can you lay ſo ſcandalous a Crime to ſo guiltleſs a Gentlemans charge?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Nay, Huſſey, I can prove 'twas he that ſtole 'em, and you were his Confederate; and I'll have you both hang'd.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Did not he, by the malice and inſtigation of the Devil, come to you at the wicked hour of Midnight at my Parlour-window, which you open'd to him, and let him feloniouſly in at it to rob me?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Oh fie, Sir, 'tis not wide enough for him to put his hand through.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Bear witneſs, Gentlemen, ſhe confeſſes he put his hand through; and I'll ſwear the Devil ſtood behinde him and thruſt his bodie after it. I ſay, 'twas he that robb'd me, and I can prove. 'twas he that robb'd me; and I'll have him hang'd like a Thief as he is. Two thouſand Ducatoons!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I pitie your caſe, and have bethought a way to get your Pearl agen.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: The Pearl agen!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis an infallible way: It muſt do in ſpight of fate. If I do not bring 'em agen, nay, though the Thief had ſwallow'd 'em—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Swallowed 'em! Pox choak him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nay, though he had ſwallow'd 'em, I'd make him diſgorge 'em, but you ſhould have 'em agen.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, this is divinely ſpoken! But how, how, dear Senior?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You muſt know, this Monſieur is a profeſt Aſtrologer, and by the by, to ſerve a friend or ſo, can conjure; that is, can raiſe the Devil: You underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Raiſe the Devil!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: To raiſe him in an honeſt way's nothing. Monſieur, give him a taſte of your ſkill.

div.stage: Monſieur makes a great many ridiculous poſtures, then falls a conjuring in a great deal of bluſtering cramp words.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh hold, hold, dear Sir, hold, hold.
Oh, Sir, I have not been at Confeſſion theſe two years; let me but go to Confeſſion firſt, and then raiſe the Devil and welcome.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Your humble Serviture; commanda me, and me vill raiſe de Spirit, de Tunder, de Lightning, de Cloud, de Vind, and de Tempeſt.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Aye, but are you ſure they can raiſe the Pearl agen?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Morbleau, de great Devil not able to raiſe de little Pearl! fee, fee, Senior.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: But are you ſure he can get at 'em?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Noting ſurer, noting ſurer. Rater den fail, me vill ſend him to Sea to fiſh for more.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, I profeſs 'tis a good-natur'd Devil. But hark you, Sir, are you ſure 'tis a Devil that you dare truſt?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Journee, vit mine whole Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Two thouſand Ducatoons is a tempting ſum; and if he ſhou'd keep 'em when he has got 'em?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Courage, fear noting.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Sir, the place of his Operation is at his Study at my houſe; we muſt deſire your company thither.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, I'll onely order my Servants to have a care of my Daughter, and go along with you.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Senior, de whole Famile muſt go along wit you, de young Son and de fair Daughter; dey may be concern in de Robbery. Pardonna me, Madam; my Art ſpare no body.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Aye, now I think on't, ſhe ſhall go with us. If Dorido and ſhe have laid their heads together, he'll firk it out of her with a vengeance.
Senior, pray beg his Lordſhips pardon, and tell him his Neck-lace is at preſent in Huckſters hands; but we'll firk it out of 'em with a vengeance. Clo, come along with me.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Tief, ſteal de Jewel!
De teeviſh hide of Rogua me vill drub,
Journee, by Lucifere and Belzebub.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Well, Wife, now give us a little of your Entertainment at the Monaſtery.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis extreme fine!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye, but I would fain have you deſcribe it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?
Oh, 'tis the ſweeteſt, rareſt Entertainment in the world!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye, but let us hear the particulars. What did you ſee? what did you hear? what did you do? what did you ſay? Come, let's know all.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I ſhall be undone, if this diſcourſe hold.

What did I ſee? what did I do? Oh 'tis not to be expreſt! In the firſt place, I went along with Sabina, and ſhe led me into the moſt delicious ſweet place—But, Huſband, I have News to tell you: I heard juſt now of a famous Aſtrologer newly come to Town.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But you don't tell me your Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, you can't imagine it, unleſs you ſaw it, ſo rich, and ſo divine—Well, but this Aſtrologer is ſo wittie and ſo ingenious a man, that I long to aſk him a queſtion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: With all my heart. But what did the Nuns do?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, they knelt, and they pray'd, and they ſung, and they—Prethee, my dear, let us go to him; I have a queſtion to aſk him, you little think of. Gueſs, my dear, prethee gueſs—I am ſo
aſhamed—Well, but for once I'll tell you: I'd aſk him how many Children we ſhall have; I do ſo long for a Childe, and I would have it a Boy, that it may be like thee, my dear.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Kinde dear Rogue! Well, but you are the ſtrangeſt woman! I aſk you about the Nuns, and you anſwer about Boys and Girls. Prethee, dear, I do ſo long for this Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, now I think on't, I'll have my will before yours. You ſhall go along with me to this Aſtrologer's, and then I'll tell you my Entertainment: I vow and ſwear I won't tell you elſe. Now, do, make me forſworn.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Well, thou art ſo croſs!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Beſides, this Aſtrologer lives at Senior Claudio's; and I am ſure we ſhall be welcome thither.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Senior Claudio's! Boy, your Miſtriſſes Vail, and my Sword and Cloak.

div.stage: The Scene opens, and diſcovers Monſieur's Study. Enter Claudio, Avaritio, Clorinia, and Valerio. Enter at another door Monſieur in a Conjuring-gown, and Dorido diſguiſed in the ſame habit.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: 'Tis a very odde place, Senior.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: The Spirits he deals with, like it the better.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Velcome into mine Cell. Te Star, and de Conſtellation—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The wandring Spirits of the Air.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: De ſuperlunary and de ſublunary Miniſter—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Demons and the Cacodemons—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: De eterial Peripatetick—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And all the Coeleſtial Outacouſtions—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: De great Devil and de little Devil, my foy, votre tres humble Serviture.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pray thank 'em, and tell 'em I am their humble Servant. Dear Sir, ſtand by me,
I no not like thoſe Outacouſtions. But hark you, Sir, if a man may be ſo bold, what kind of things are thoſe Demons and Cacodemons?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Demons and Cacodemons? why, dey be de Pimp to de great Devil; me ſend 'em on de Errand, de Meſſage; dey pierce into de Eart, dive into de Sea; flie in de Air, mount into de Cloud; dey raiſe de Wind, de Lightning, de Tunder; and obey me in all my command.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pray deſire his Devilſhip to uſe no Ceremonie with me. Can't I get my Pearl without all theſe Demons and Cacodemons?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Oh, no, Senior; it be deir buſineſs to ſerve my friend.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Pray deſire his Devilſhip not to take it ill.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: He will no take it ill.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Two thouſand Ducatoons is a great loſs.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Do not me tell you—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I vow and ſwear I would not trouble him, if I could poſſibly help it.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: It be no trouble.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I would not gain his anger for twice the ſum.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Journee, he vill be no anger—

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I profeſs, if I thought he would—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Morbleau, I ſay he vill be no anger. Do you tink me lye?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I ha'done, Sir, I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Now, Sir, me vill proceed to my Operation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Great Sir, your Art and Experience in this profound ſtudy, needs no advice.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Alas, me underſtand noting. Me have de little civilitie from de Spirit, de little command ore de Familiar; dat be all.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I profeſs he's a modeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Now, Sir, place a de Circle on de right hand, and anoder on de left; var boon.
sp.stage: Dorido places two Circles on each ſide the Stage.
sp.p: Now, Sir, ſet de fair Lady in dat Circle, and me vill ſet de ancient Gentleman in dis: var boon!

div.stage: They place Avaritio in one Circle, and Clorinia in the other.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My dear Clorinia!

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: Now, Dorido, if fortune favour us!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Now, Sir, vatever you ſee, or vatever you hear, you no ſpeak nor ſtir: take care you be ſafe in dat Circle.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Aye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: My Leonora here! Senior Pedro, this viſit is wondrous kinde: What your Lady too! This favour is extraordinary. What kinde Gale has brought ſuch fair Company to viſit my poor houſe!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My Wife, you muſt know, has a ſtrange deſire to put a Queſtion to the Cunning man you keep.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, I hope you'll pardon a bold intruder? But Curioſity's a venial ſin in our Sex. Pray excuſe may Bluſhes when I tell you before my Huſband that I have extremely long'd for that ſatisfaction which can be onely had at Senior Claudio's.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: This kindneſs is beyond expreſſion!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I know you'll call me a confident creature for this: but I vow 'tis a fault I cannot help.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a wittie charming Rogue! She courts me before her Huſband's face.

Well, Madam, the honour you have vouchſafed your humble Servant, has ſo obliged me, that if there be any Art or Magick in the world that can pleaſe a fair Lady—Sir, you'll pardon me—by this kiſs you ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye, good Senior, let her have it: for uds-bodikins if you don't, ſhe'll lead me ſo troubleſom a life—

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, leave her to my care. Senior,
[to Avar.] here's a little important buſineſs has made me rude. Monſieur, you muſt uſe a little ſlight of hand with this Gentleman, and get that Lady off for me; you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Senior, me vill do't.

Sir,
[to Pedro.] by de favour of your good Star, you be come in de fortunate minute of my Operation. Here be de Gentleman dat have been robb'd of de Jewel vort Two touſand Ducatoons.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And can you help him to't agen?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Journee, wit as much eaſe as me drink, or me ſleep.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, Wife, this is a fine man indeed!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Me beg your patience.
Remember my councel; no ſpeak, no ſtir from dat Circle.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Whatever you ſee or hear, be not afraid, 'tis all but Jugling.
sp.stage: [to Leonora. Monſieur conjures, and it thunders.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: What ſhall I do! what ſhall become of me!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Wife, wife, oloh!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Heaven have mercy upon us. Claudio, Valerio, ſtand by me.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: O fee, de coward; fear noting.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Wife, wife, oloh.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: O death, hell, what ſhall I do!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: O fee, in de Circle, de Circle.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, if you have any pity for me, don't fright me at this unmerciful rate.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Morbleau, you be de ſtrange man in de whole world: none but de boy, de ſhilde, be frighted at de Tunder: De grave Cavalier, and be fraid!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I can't help it, if it would ſave my life. The next clap of Thunder ſtrikes me dead.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, the Gentleman ſays right; it makes me tremble every joynt.

div.stage: It thunders agen, and Leonora falls down in a Trap.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oloh!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Dear Monſieur, I love thee. Now will I flie into my dear Leonora's arms.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh my Wife, my Wife, my Wife!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: De grave Gentleman, and cry! For ſhame, for ſhame!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: You may ſee what comes of your wicked Conjuring; the Devil has fetcht away one of our company already.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye, aye, the Devil has got her. She's gone, and I ſhall never ſee her agen!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I am afraid the houſe will fall upon our heads.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh my Wife!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Journee, vat be de matter? You ſhall have your Wife agen ſafe and ſound, ſafe and ſound.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, no, the Devil has tore her to pieces by this time! I am undone, you wicked man you! If I had but received all her Portion, and ſhe had gone to the Devil then, 'twould ne're ha'vext me: But ſhe's under age, and I have not been married this half year, and I ſhall be hang'd for bringing her hither. I am acceſſary to her Murder. Oh my Wife, my Wife!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Morbleau, you ſhall be no hang, nor ſhe be no murder: ſhe be alive and var well; nay, ſhe be in dis room, dis var room ſtill.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: In this Room!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Say that agen.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Me have onely caſt a Miſt before your eye.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: A Miſt!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: She be in dis Room; onely ſhe be inviſible.

sp.speaker: Avar. and Ped.
sp.p: Inviſible!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Dis be noting but de trick of my Skill, my Art: me can make de whole Famile de whole inviſible, ſi you play, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And are you ſure my poor Dear is onely inviſible?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Noting elſe. She be in dis Room ſtill. Hiſt, dare ſhe go.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Dare, juſt dare.
O fee, ſhe be too nimble for you, you canno catch her; ſhe ſerve you de ſlippery trick.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, I am ſatisfied you can do Miracles, and all that; but dear Sir, help me to her as ſoon as poſſibly you can.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: She ſhall come by degree: De Miſt before your eye ſhall vaniſh preſant.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, pray make an end of my buſineſs, I am not very well, I am all-o're in a cold ſweat; and therefore pray help me to my Pearl agen, that I may go home to bed.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Bring in de Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Prieſts, Sir, for what?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Becauſe me raiſe de Spirit, and when de Prieſt ſtand by, de Spirit have no power.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: But are you ſure they ha'nt? wo'nt he tear me to pieces?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: No, no, dey be as innocent as de Lamb.

div.stage: Enter a Priest, who goes to Dorido and Clorinia; and Truro in a Prieſts habit, who goes to Avaritio.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Dear Divinitie, ſtand by me.

sp.speaker: Trur.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Sir, I am your protectour.

div.stage: Monſieur conjures. Aſcenda, aſcenda, aſcenda! A Spirit aſcends.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The Devil, the Devil, the Devil!

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I am dead, dead, ſtark dead—

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Courage, dis be de harmleſs innocent Spirit; dis Devil hurt no body.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, the ſight of him kills me!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Kill! O fee, he be de good-natur'd Devil; he be ſo far from killing, dat me vill make him dance to entertain you.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Dance, ſaid you!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Me can command de Muſick in de Air.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.p: Now kneel, and take her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My dear Clorinia, this bleſſing is ſo raviſhing, that I can ſcarce contain my Joys.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Upon thy knees, Clo! that's a good girl; pray for me, pray for me.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Aye, Senior, ſhe be very good Daughter, de pious Lady. But now obſerve my Art.

div.stage: Monſieur circles his Wand, and the Spirit dances.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Now, Sir, dere be de Jewel; make him a ver low bow, paſs him a Compliman, kiſs his hand, and tank him.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Kiſs hand, ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Vat, vill be uncivil to de generous kind Spirit?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Uncivil, with a Pox! I dare not come neer him.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Vat vill you no take de Jewel?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Let him but lay it down, and ſtand a little further off, and I dare venture to take it.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Oh dat be no good faſhion. You mus-take it from his own hand. Forward, forward, courage.
sp.stage: [Thruſts him forward. He takes the Jewel.
sp.p: Your Compliman, your Compliman.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you kill me, you kill me!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Your tank, your tank.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: I ſhall die, I ſhall die!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Your tank.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: And pleaſe—your Devilſhip—I am your Devilſhips moſt—humble Servant—I kiſs your fair hand, and ſo I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Now vere be you hurt?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall never claw off this fright.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My Dear, art thou come agen!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Did me no tell you ſhe wou'd come agen?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My Dear, where haſt thou been?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Oh, I have been the Lord knows where! I have been in a Trance, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: A Trance!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: When I ſunk under the ground, a great two-handed Devil got me into his Cell, and caught me in his arms and held me ſo cloſe, that he had like to have ſtifl'd me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Stifl'd thee, poor Rogue!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And would you think it? he had ſcarce let me go two minutes, but the furious Devil caught me ſo agen.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Come, Wife, let us be gone. I have been frighted almoſt out of my wits. Senior, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Are you going, Senior?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I thought to have put a Queſtion—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh, no more Queſtions, no raiſing of damn'd Spirits, good Wife.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But ſome other time will do better. I am very well ſatisfi'd at preſent.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Dear Madam, adieu.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Clo, and Valerio, come, have me home to bed. Oh ſick, ſick!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir, your Daughter mus ſtay, and go to bed wit dat Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: How! what's this?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, your Son-in-Law, the happy Dorido.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: And your dutiful Daughter Clorinia.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Beg your Pardon and your Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Come, Sir, forgive 'em; they have lov'd one another, and now have made one another happy.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Huſſey, is all this true?

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.p: I can't deny what's made in Heav'n. Yes, Sir, he is my Huſband.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Cheats, Rogues, Villains, I am betray'd!

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Betray! Oh no, your Daughter be onely marri'd to dat Gentleman by a trick of my invention; dat's all.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: All, ſaid you? Gypſie, how durſt you play the Traytor, and ſee the Devil ſo neer you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Twas her beſt policie to avoid him. The Devil could have no power over her whilſt ſhe was at ſo pious a work.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: We, Senior; de Devil have no pow'r to take de fair Lady, eſpecial when ſhe be taking de fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Not take her, with a Pox! If he would not take her then, let him take her now: for ſhe ſhall never get one Croſs from me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: However, let us have your Bleſſing, if we have nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Diſſembling, cheating, jilting Varlets, go hang your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have been ſeeking for Senior Dorido, and was directed hither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: An't pleaſe you, Sir, your rich Unkle at Madrid, Senior Fabricio, God reſt his Soul, is dead; and dying without Iſſue, you are left Heir to his Eſtate. I am come Poſt to inform you, and deſire you to come to take poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Heir to Senior Fabricio's Eſtate!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Twenty thouſand Crowns per annum, is a Bleſſing comes not every day.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Twenty thouſand Crowns per annum!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But is my Uncle dead?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Aye, ſo the Gentleman ſays. But be not afflicted; alas, we muſt all die.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am not ſo much afflicted at his death, as at your anger and diſpleaſure for marrying your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Why truly, Senior Dorido, I have been a little angry with you; but I vow my anger's ſoon o're. And for any ill will I bear you, God knows my Soul—
Fabricio's Eſtate!
Why really, Sir, I always had a great eſteem for your perſon. Your Father was my very intimate Acquaintance, a worthy honeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But, Sir, ſhall we have your Bleſſing?

sp.speaker: Avar.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, what do you mean! Riſe, riſe; my Bleſſing on you both.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Monſieur, I ſhall ſtudy to requite this kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Sir, it be always de grand buſineſs of de French man, to oblige de fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But here—
—I muſt die a Debtour.

sp.speaker: Monſ.
sp.p: Vell, Sir, now me have done my magick Charm,
Next Circle dat you make be in her arm.
My Conjuring Art can boaſt var little merit;
'Tis de fair Lady dat can raiſe de Spirit.

lg.l: BEgar, de Play be done, and now me gueſs,
Journee, me Conjure vat be de ſucceſs.
You tink de Play be dull, me tink ſo too:
And, Gallant, am not I a Witch, Morbleau?
Play take, and Autor be ſo grand a fool
To turn de French Nation to ridicule?
Dere's no ſuch ting in nature: No begar,
De French-man be de Wit in Anglitar.
Dough he be fool in France, dat be no matter;
Shange but de Scene, and come but croſs de water
In Engliſh Air, he ſtrait turn man of part,
Get de Lords money, and de Ladies heart.
And ſhall
De Engliſh Fop abuſe him on de Stage?
Journee, all my French blood be in a rage.
Damn d'Engliſh Acteur, Engliſh Teatre,
Dere's no ſuch ting as Wit nor Acting dere.
De Wit, de Senſe, de Fame, and de Renown,
Be in de French Troop at toder end o'Town.
Dere Player be brisk aery Spark, here Dog
Of Actor, more like heavie Engliſh Log.
Beſide, de Engliſh fool breed Beauties here,
And when gay Miſs does on de Stage appear,
Strait keeping Spark, undo de Teatre.
Dere's no ſuch danger 'mong de wiſer French,
Dere matron Actreſs with grave face, fat paunch,
And greaſie look, more fit for Bawd den Wench.
Here dull Comedian ſpend Ten touſand pound,
Build houſe, and act togeder ſeav'n year round.
Begar, dat be no good French faſhion; Dey,
Like true Knight Erran, ſcorn ſo long a ſtay;
Act but a veek or fortnight, and away.
No Houſe, no Beauty, no Eſtate t'engage;
Journee, dere be no Ruining deir Stage.
